title: Lowest bidder wins: the calculations behind a $31bn rail deal
text:
One wild thing in German banking to start: Deutsche Bank has pulled a research report accusing German financial regulators and the country's outgoing conservative-led government of serious failures less than two weeks ahead of the hotly contested federal election. Here's our must read story from Olaf Storbeck in Frankfurt.

Choo-choo: Canadian Pacific deal with Kansas City Southern is back on track

Six months ago the Financial Times revealed that Canadian Pacific had agreed to acquire Kansas City Southern, the first major railway merger in two decades. 

On Wednesday the two companies renewed their vows. What happened in between was one of the most riveting takeover battles in recent memory. 

It pitted CP and its larger rival Canadian National against each other to secure an asset that will create the first ever end-to-end railway line connecting Canada to Mexico through the US. Here's a quick recap. 

On March 21 CP announced it had reached an agreement to buy KCS for $275 a share, comprising $90 in cash and the remainder in CP stock, valuing the US railroad at about $29bn including debt. 

KCS's board had a change of heart less than two month later. On May 13 CN successfully gatecrashed the deal with a cash-and-stock offer worth $320 a share, valuing the company at about $34bn including debt. 

At this point, you'd think that the only way CP could make a comeback was with a bid higher than CN's. That didn't happen. Why? All along, CP was convinced that theirs was the only deal that could obtain regulatory approval.

CP's strategy to wait on the sidelines worked. 

On August 31, the US Surface Transportation Board rejected CN's request to create a temporary voting trust, a key component in how the deal was structured because it would've allowed KCS shareholders to get paid before receiving full regulatory approval.  

That was the turning point. 

The message from the regulator was clear: CN's deal with KCS, which would have created the third-largest US railway operator, held the potential to harm the public interest. Game over. 

Before the STB made its views known, CP sweetened its old offer, increasing it to $300 a share. 

It was a tactical move to facilitate a swift re-engagement with KCS, especially since a CP-KCS merger would not face much regulatory push back as it would create the smallest out of six rail operators in North America.

That's exactly what happened on Wednesday. KCS terminated its deal with CN and announced its new combination with CP. 

For its trouble CN is walking away with $1.4bn in pay-offs. But it now faces a revolt from one of its biggest shareholders, TCI's Chris Hohn, who is seeking to overthrow its leadership and some of its board. 

GreenSky: David Solomon and the circle of life

Goldman Sachs chief David Solomon is on a dealmaking spree. 

Just weeks after snapping up NN Investment Partners, the investment management arm of the Dutch insurer NN Group, for €1.6bn, he has struck another multibillion-dollar acquisition. 

Goldman said on Wednesday it has agreed to buy GreenSky, the online loans provider, for $2.2bn.  

The deal comes as the US investment bank tries to entrench itself in the consumer lending business, a key profit driver for Wall Street rivals including JPMorgan Chase.

Goldman launched its own online lending platform in 2016, which has had its own issues, as reported by The Wall Street Journal. 

Named after Goldman's founder, Marcus emerged on the scene during the marketplace lending boom when companies such as Lending Club and OnDeck promised to disrupt traditional lenders by facilitating loans to borrowers through online platforms. 

The money mostly came from external financing, however, often from the very institutions they were trying to displace. 

GreenSky is no exception. The company, which offers “buy now, pay later” services, relies on funding partners such as banks for its loans. It services a $9bn portfolio but has struggled to achieve the success of some of its peers in the sector.

Before the announcement of the deal, GreenSky shares were down 70 per cent from their $23 initial public offering price in 2018. 

The Atlanta-based company has also been criticised for its lending practices with The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau handing GreenSky a $2.5m fine in July for enabling merchants to take out loans on behalf of consumers without their knowledge. 

GreenSky and Goldman are no strangers, of course. 

The investment bank took the lead role in its IPO, splitting about $50m in fees. Months later, when GreenSky shares had declined by more than two-thirds, Goldman was forced to admit that it had been “wrong” about the company and downgraded GreenSky's 12-month price target from $31 to $11.

Now Goldman has snapped it up for $12.11 a share, to be paid in Goldman stock. 

So goes the circle of life on Wall Street. 

When things get hostile in Tokyo

Last week the man who probably ranks as Japan's most flamboyant and certainly most outspoken banker, Yoshitaka Kitao, caught Japan's buttoned-up financial sector by surprise.

Kitao's online brokerage SBI launched an unsolicited tender offer that would more than double its existing stake in Shinsei Bank to 48 per cent. 

That would have been bold enough on its own, writes the FT's Leo Lewis from Tokyo. 

But Kitao also wants to oust the Shinsei board and replace it with one of his own suggestion. That's aggressive stuff to throw at a company with which, until very recently, SBI was hoping to secure deeper business ties. 

The FT has been tracking for some time the gradual establishment of hostile deals into the mainstream of Japanese dealmaking, but this fight seems more likely than others to become a landmark.

The fun really began on Tuesday when the FT broke the news that Shinsei had engaged Morgan Stanley as an adviser on takeover defence strategies, and that the tactic currently under discussion was a “poison pill” that could in theory see Shinsei offering heavily dilutive stock acquisition rights. 

The reality, though, is that Shinsei's plan is primarily about buying time: the poison pill would have to be voted on by shareholders at an extraordinary meeting, which would require a two-thirds majority of its investors to approve. 

SBI's 20 per cent stake makes that bar almost impossibly high, but it does at least mean that everything — including SBI's tender offer — goes into limbo for some months. 

Plenty of time for Shinsei to come up either with alternative bidders or to sit down again with SBI and discuss closer business ties on friendlier terms.

Whatever happens, precedents will be set and the entire market is watching this one very closely indeed.

Job moves

  • DD exclusive: PJT Partners has hired the veteran European dealmaker René Proglio as a partner in its advisory group based in Paris. Proglio left Morgan Stanley in May after 17 years, most recently serving as a vice-chair and country head for France. Before joining Morgan Stanley, Proglio was a partner at Arthur Andersen where he spent 20 years. 

  • Rothschild has appointed the former UK cabinet secretary Mark Sedwill to its supervisory board. He will replace Anthony de Rothschild. 

  • Les Wood, who has been chief financial officer of Tullow Oil since 2017, will step down at the end of March.

  • Robert Stebbins, former general counsel for the US Securities and Exchange Commission, has rejoined Willkie Farr as a partner in New York, where he will head the firm's corporate governance practice. 

  • Houlihan Lokey has hired Stephen Lee as a managing director and head of its technology and cyber security practice. He joins in Chicago from KPMG.
